intro: Leptosiphon nudatus, commonly known as the nakedflower morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family, characterized by its climbing habit and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant produces small, pale blue to white flowers that bloom in the early morning, hence its common name. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and often hairy, while its stems are slender and twining. The plant is adapted to arid environments and is often found in rocky or sandy soils.
